questions.text: What is the term used to describe the type of cell in the body that has the ability to give rise to the highest number of other cells?
questions.solution:
Correct option: A

  • Totipotent cells are capable of differentiating into all cell types, including the cells of the embryo and the extraembryonic tissues. They have the ability to form all cell lineages, both embryonic and extraembryonic. Totipotent cells are found in the early stages of embryonic development, up to the 4-cell stage. They have the highest developmental potential and can give rise to a complete organism.

Incorrect options:

Option B: Multipotent: Multipotent cells are capable of differentiating into multiple, but not all, cell types. They can give rise to cells of a closely related cell lineage or tissue type.

Option C: Pluripotent: Pluripotent cells can differentiate into cells of all three germ layers (endoderm, mesoderm, and ectoderm) but cannot form the extraembryonic tissues.

Option D: Lineage stem cells: This term is not commonly used in the context of cell potency. It may refer to stem cells that are capable of differentiating into specific lineages but not all cell types.

questions.text:
A patient underwent ileal resection and subsequently developed anemia along with peripheral neuropathy and features of SACD. Laboratory findings show hemoglobin (Hb) of 9 g/dL and mean corpuscular volume (MCV) of 110 fL.

What is the most likely cause of his anemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Vitamin B12 deficiency

Explanation:

Ileal resection can lead to vitamin B12 deficiency, as the terminal ileum is the primary site for absorption of the vitamin B12–intrinsic factor complex; this deficiency commonly results in macrocytic anemia, reflected by an elevated MCV of 110 fL.

  • Terminal ileum: Site of vitamin B12 absorption (B12–intrinsic factor complex).
    • Ileal resection → impaired B12 absorption → Vitamin B12 deficiency.
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency:
    • Causes macrocytic (megaloblastic) anemia → MCV > 100 fL.
    • May present with neurological symptoms (e.g., paresthesia, ataxia).
    • Lab findings:
      • ↓ Hemoglobin
      • ↑ MCV (e.g., 110 fL)
      • ↑ LDH, ↑ indirect bilirubin, ↓ reticulocyte count

Incorrect Options:

Iron deficiency anemia (Option A) is unlikely because it typically causes microcytic anemia (low MCV), not macrocytic anemia.

Folic acid deficiency (Option C) causes macrocytic anemia, but folate is absorbed in the jejunum, not the ileum, making it less likely after ileal resection.

Sideroblastic anemia (Option D) usually presents with microcytic or dimorphic anemia, and it's not related to ileal absorption.

questions.text: Bernard-Soulier syndrome is caused by a defect in which of the following platelet glycoproteins?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - GpIb/IX complex:

Explanation:

Bernard-Soulier syndrome is caused by a defect in the GpIb/IX complex on platelets.

  • GpIb/IX complex is the receptor for von Willebrand factor (vWF) → mediates platelet adhesion to subendothelial collagen after vascular injury.
  • In Bernard–Soulier syndrome, this adhesion step is impaired → defective platelet plug formation.
  • Labs/Findings:
    • Normal or low platelet count
    • Prolonged bleeding time
    • Giant platelets on peripheral smear
    • Normal platelet aggregation with ADP, collagen, epinephrine, but absent aggregation with ristocetin (not corrected by adding normal plasma, unlike vWD).

Incorrect Options:

GpIIb/IIIa (Option A):

  • Function: Binds fibrinogen → platelet aggregation.
  • Defect causes Glanzmann thrombasthenia, not BSS.
  • Lab: Normal platelet count, defective aggregation with all agonists except ristocetin.

GpIa/IIa (Option C):

  • Function: Binds collagen (supports platelet adhesion).
  • Defects are rare and cause mild bleeding disorders, not the classic BSS picture.

GpIV (Option D): Also called CD36; role in platelet adhesion and scavenger receptor function.

questions.text: A young boy presents with joint swelling after a fall. Lab investigations show normal PT and raised aPTT. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Haemophilia:

Explanation:

This presentation matches haemophilia because:

  • Joint swelling after trauma → suggests hemarthrosis, which is typical of coagulation factor deficiencies, especially haemophilia.

  • Normal PT → extrinsic pathway is intact.

  • Prolonged aPTT → intrinsic pathway defect (Factors VIII, IX, XI).

  • Haemophilia A = Factor VIII deficiency; Haemophilia B = Factor IX deficiency.

Incorrect Options:

Von Willebrand Disease (Option A): usually has prolonged aPTT (due to low factor VIII) and mucocutaneous bleeding (epistaxis, menorrhagia), not deep joint bleeds as the main feature.

Iron Deficiency Anaemia (IDA) (Option C): causes pallor and fatigue, not isolated coagulation abnormalities.

Platelet function disorder (Option D): causes mucosal bleeding and petechiae, not hemarthrosis; PT and aPTT are usually normal.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a haemostatic agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C.

Boric acid: Boric acid is not commonly used as a hemostatic agent. It is primarily used in various industrial and pharmaceutical applications, but it does not have specific hemostatic properties.

Incorrect Option

Option A: Zeolite: Zeolite is a mineral-based compound that has been used as a hemostatic agent. It works by absorbing water and promoting clot formation at the site of bleeding.

Option B. Chitosan: Chitosan is a biopolymer derived from chitin, which is found in the exoskeleton of crustaceans. Chitosan-based products have been used as hemostatic agents due to their ability to promote clotting and accelerate wound healing.

Option D. Kaolin: Kaolin is a naturally occurring clay mineral that has hemostatic properties. It acts by activating the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade and promoting clot formation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Von Willebrand's disease is incorrect?

choices.text: Type 2 von Willebrand disease is associated with a moderate bleeding tendency.
Type 3 von Willebrand disease is associated with a complete absence of von Willebrand factor.
Type 1 von Willebrand disease presents with severe bleeding since childhood.
Type 2 von Willebrand disease includes subtypes with varying defects in the von Willebrand factor.

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Type 1 von Willebrand disease presents with severe bleeding since childhood:

  • Type 1 von Willebrand disease presents with mild deficiency of Von Willebrand factor and, hence, mild bleeding.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are correct regarding Von Willebrand's disease.

questions.text: Stellate granuloma is found in:
questions.solution:
Correct option: A

  • Stellate granuloma is a histopathological finding characterized by central necrosis surrounded by histiocytes, giant cells, and lymphocytes arranged in a stellate or star-shaped pattern. It is commonly associated with cat scratch disease, which is caused by the bacterium Bartonella henselae. In cat scratch disease, stellate granulomas can be found in the affected lymph nodes, indicating the immune response to the infection.

Incorrect options:

Option B: Leprosy: Stellate granulomas are not a characteristic finding in leprosy. Leprosy is associated with granulomatous inflammation but presents with different histopathological features.

Option C: Coccidiomycosis: Coccidiomycosis is a fungal infection caused by Coccidioides species and is not typically associated with stellate granulomas.

Option D: Histoplasmosis: Histoplasmosis is a fungal infection caused by Histoplasma capsulatum and does not typically present with stellate granulomas.

questions.text: Leiden mutation is of factor:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: V

  • Leiden mutation is a genetic mutation of factor V, also known as Factor V Leiden. Factor V is a protein involved in the blood clotting process. The Leiden mutation refers to a specific mutation in the factor V gene, which leads to an increased risk of abnormal blood clot formation.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Factor VIII- Factor VIII is another protein involved in the blood clotting process, but it is not associated with the Leiden mutation.

Option C: Factor I- Factor I, also known as fibrinogen, is a protein involved in the formation of blood clots, but it is not associated with the Leiden mutation.

Option D: Factor X- Factor X is another protein involved in the blood clotting process, but it is not associated with the Leiden mutation.

questions.text: Stellate granuloma is found in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cat scratch disease

Explanation:

  • Stellate granulomas are irregular star-shaped granulomas commonly found in Cat Scratch Disease (CSD), caused by Bartonella henselae.
  • Causative agent: Bartonella henselae (transmitted via cat scratches/bites).
  • Histology: Stellate-shaped granulomas with central necrosis and neutrophilic infiltrate.
  • Symptoms: Painful lymphadenopathy (axillary, cervical) with fever. Resolves spontaneously in immunocompetent individuals.

 

Leprosy (Option B) granulomas contain foamy macrophages (Virchow cells) and Langhans giant cells, not stellate granulomas.

Coccidiomycosis (Option C) forms caseating granulomas, not stellate granulomas.

Histoplasmosis (Option D) forms well-defined granulomas with caseation commonly found in the lungs.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female with a bleeding disorder following autosomal dominant inheritance. She gave the history of her father and sister having the same bleeding disorders. What is the most likely disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Von Willebrand disease

Explanation:

  • Von Willebrand disease (VWD) is the most common inherited bleeding disorder caused by defective or deficient von Willebrand factor (vWF).
  • It follows an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern, affecting both males and females, with a 50% chance of passing the disorder to offspring.

 

  • Von Willebrand disease is clinically and molecularly heterogeneous, with three identified types, each exhibiting a variety of phenotypes.

vWD type 1

vWD Type 2

vWD Type 3

  • Autosomal dominant.
  • The most common type.
  • Mild to moderate vWF deficiency.
  • Quantitative defect.
  • Point substitutions prevent the vWF protein from maturing or cause it to leave the plasma quickly.

 
  • Autosomal dominant.
  • Qualitative defect.


Types: 2A, 2B, 2M, 2N

  • 2A (Most common) - Decrease in binding between vWF and Gp1b/9 Missense mutations cause faulty multimer formation → the most active forms of vWF, i.e. large- and intermediate-sized multimers are absent.
  • 2B - Increase in binding between vWF and Gp1b/9
  • 2M - VWF-dependent platelet adhesion is decreased. VWF binding to platelets is impaired. Type 2M VWD typically has mild to moderate mucocutaneous bleeding
  • 2N - There is a marked decline in the binding affinity for factor VIII. The level of factor VIII is lower when compared to the VWF: Ag. This led to misdiagnosis as haemophilia A.
  • Autosomal recessive.
  • Quantitative defect.
  • Produced by frameshift mutations or deletions affecting both alleles (autosomal recessive), which produce little or no vWF.
  • Factor VIII levels are also lowered because vWF stabilizes factor VIII in the blood, and the resulting bleeding condition is severe.

 

 

Hemophilia A (Option B) is an X-linked recessive disorder that mainly affects males, with females being carriers. This makes it an unlikely diagnosis for this patient, who has a family history involving females.

Christmas disease (Option C) is an X-linked recessive disorder; hence, this condition is primarily seen in males, and it is less likely to be the cause of an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern.

Factor X deficiency (Option D) is a rare bleeding disorder that can be inherited in autosomal recessive patterns, which causes the clotting process to take longer than normal.

questions.text: A young patient presents with a large retroperitoneal haemorrhage and a history of intermittent knee swelling during strenuous exercise. There is no history of mucosal bleeding. Which of the following deficiencies is responsible for the condition mentioned above?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Factors VIII and IX

Explanation:

  • The patient's symptoms (large retroperitoneal haemorrhage and knee swelling) suggest haemophilia, which is typically caused by deficiencies in Factors VIII (Hemophilia A) or IX (Hemophilia B).
  • This condition is characterised by spontaneous or trauma-induced joint and muscle bleeds but not mucosal bleeding, which is distinct from von Willebrand disease or platelet dysfunction.

  • Hemophilia C is due to factor 11 deficiency, an autosomal recessive condition. Bleeding episodes are generally milder than in Hemophilia A and B.

Incorrect Options:

GP1b/IX (Option B): This is associated with Bernard-Soulier syndrome, a platelet disorder characterised by defective platelet adhesion. It leads to mucosal bleeding, which is absent in this case.

Von Willebrand factor (Option C) deficiency causes von Willebrand disease, which primarily results in mucosal bleeding (e.g., nosebleeds, gum bleeding) and not typically large retroperitoneal haemorrhages or joint bleeds.

Lupus anticoagulant (Option D): This is associated with antiphospholipid syndrome, leading to an increased risk of thrombosis (clots), not bleeding. It does not explain the bleeding symptoms described in this patient.

questions.text: Which of the following shows maximum amplitude on thromboelastography?
questions.solution:
• Thromboelastography (TEG) measures the viscoelastic properties of blood as it clots.
  • The maximum amplitude (MA) on TEG reflects the strength of the clot, which is primarily determined by the number and function of platelets and the fibrinogen concentration.
  • The platelets contribute most significantly to the clot's strength and the MA value.

 

Thromboelastography (TEG) is a diagnostic tool used to evaluate coagulation profiles and guide management with transfusions and hemostatic therapies. Studies show that TEG can reduce blood product usage by up to 40%, decrease postoperative length of stay, and lower the risk of reoperation.

 

TEG measures the viscoelastic properties of blood as clotting occurs. The resulting data is plotted on a graph with time on the x-axis and amplitude (clot strength) on the y-axis. Key values include:

  • Reaction time (R): The time it takes for the clot strength to reach an amplitude of 2 mm.
  • Kinetics (K): The time from R to when the amplitude reaches 20 mm.
  • α-angle: The angle formed by a line from R to the point where K intersects with the 20 mm amplitude mark.
  • Maximum amplitude (MA): The highest amplitude reached.
  • Lysis at 30 minutes (Ly30): The per cent decrease in amplitude 30 minutes after MA (or 60 minutes in some cases).

Inference:

  • A prolonged R time may indicate coagulation factor deficiency or anticoagulation.
  • A decreased α-angle can result from hypofibrinogenemia
  • Low MA can be due to thrombocytopenia or platelet dysfunction.
  • Increased Ly30 indicates hyperfibrinolysis, often seen in severe trauma or with thrombolytic therapy.

Based on the TEG findings, targeted blood products can be administered to normalize coagulation. For example:

  • Fresh frozen plasma for prolonged R time
  • Cryoprecipitate for decreased α-angle
  • Platelets for decreased MA
  • Tranexamic acid or aminocaproic acid for increased Ly30.

questions.text: Below is an image of the coagulation cascade activation following closed endothelial injury. Identify the factor ‘L’, which combines with tissue factor to activate factor IX.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Factor VII

Explanation:

Factor VII (Proconvertin) combines with tissue factor to activate factor IX in the Coagulation Cascade following closed endothelial injury.

  • When tissue factor is exposed due to endothelial injury, it forms a complex with Factor VII. This complex activates Factor IX by cleaving it to Factor IXa, which then participates in the coagulation cascade.

 

Factor XII (Hageman factor) (Option A) is involved in the initiation of the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade. It is not directly responsible for activating factor IX in response to closed endothelial injury.

Factor VIII (antihemophilic factor A) (Option C) plays a crucial role in the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade. However, it is not involved in the direct activation of factor IX in response to closed endothelial injury.

vWF (von Willebrand factor) (Option D) is a glycoprotein that plays a vital role in platelet adhesion and aggregation. It is not directly involved in activating factor IX in the coagulation cascade following closed endothelial injury.

questions.text: Leiden mutation is of factor:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) V

Explanation:

  • The Leiden mutation is a genetic alteration in Factor V, a protein essential for blood clotting.
  • It has the autosomal dominant type of inheritance.
  • The mutation makes factor V resistant to inactivation by protein C, disrupting an antithrombotic pathway and increasing the risk of thrombosis.

Factor VIII (Option B) plays a key role in the intrinsic pathway of coagulation, where it activates Factor X to Xa, which then helps in the conversion of prothrombin to thrombin, leading to the formation of a blood clot. It is not associated with the Leiden mutation.

Factor I (Option C), also known as fibrinogen, is the precursor to fibrin, which forms the structural framework of a blood clot. When bleeding occurs, fibrinogen is converted to fibrin by the enzyme thrombin during the final steps of the coagulation cascade. It is not associated with the Leiden mutation.

Factor X (Option D), also known as the Stuart-Prower factor, is a key enzyme in the blood clotting process. It is activated to Factor Xa and plays a crucial role in converting prothrombin to thrombin, ultimately leading to the formation of a blood clot. It is not associated with the Leiden mutation.

questions.text: Which of the following clotting factor deficiencies will not affect clotting in vivo?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Factor XII

Explanation:

  • Factor XII deficiency (Hageman factor) does not significantly affect clotting in vivo, as it primarily participates in the intrinsic pathway and is involved in the activation of the fibrinolytic system and the contact activation of the clotting cascade.
  • Factor XII does not notably impair normal clotting, as other factors and pathways can compensate for its lack.
  • In contrast, Factor VII, Factor V, and Factor IX deficiencies significantly impact the clotting cascade and lead to bleeding disorders.

 

 

Factor VII (Option A) is a critical component of the extrinsic pathway of coagulation. Deficiency can lead to bleeding disorders, as it directly impacts the initiation of the clotting cascade in vivo.

Factor V (Option B) is essential for the common pathway of coagulation, acting as a cofactor for Factor Xa in the conversion of prothrombin to thrombin. Its deficiency results in impaired clotting and increases the risk of bleeding.

Factor IX (Option D) is involved in the intrinsic pathway of coagulation. Deficiency causes Hemophilia B, leading to impaired clot formation and increased bleeding risk in vivo.

questions.text: Which test evaluates the extrinsic pathway?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - PT:

  • Prothrombin time (PT) evaluates the extrinsic pathway of coagulation.
  • It measures the time it takes for blood to clot in response to activating agents that initiate the extrinsic pathway, primarily involving factors VII, X, V, II (prothrombin), and fibrinogen.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - aPTT:

  • Activated partial thromboplastin time evaluates the intrinsic pathway of coagulation.

Option C - TT:

  • Thrombin time measures the time it takes for fibrinogen to be converted into fibrin by the action of thrombin.
  • It evaluates the final common pathway of coagulation and is used to assess the activity of thrombin.

Option D - Bleeding Time:

  • Bleeding time assesses the primary hemostasis, specifically the ability of platelets to form a platelet plug and initiate clot formation.
  • It measures the time it takes for bleeding to stop after a standardized skin incision.

questions.text: A CKD patient had to undergo dialysis, and his Hb was 5.2 g/dL. So two blood transfusions were to be given. The first bag was completed in 2 hours. The second was started, and in the midway, he developed shortness of breath and hypertension. Vitals were BP: 180/120 mmHg and pulse rate: 110/min. What is the cause?
questions.solution:
Correct option B: Transfusion-related circulatory overload:

  • Transfusion-related circulatory overload (TACO) occurs when a patient receives blood or fluid too quickly.
  • In the given case, the patient undergoing dialysis received two blood transfusions. overwhelming the cardiovascular system's capacity to handle the increased volume.
  • Symptoms of TACO include shortness of breath, hypertension, elevated blood pressure, and fluid overload.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Allergic reaction: While allergic reactions can occur during transfusions, they typically present with symptoms such as itching, rash, hives, or anaphylaxis.

Option C: Transfusion-related acute lung injury:

  • TRALI is a rare but potentially serious complication of blood transfusion characterized by acute respiratory distress and pulmonary edema.
  • While shortness of breath is a symptom of TRALI, hypertension and elevated blood pressure are not typically associated with this condition.

Option D: Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction: A febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction is characterized by fever and chills during or after a blood transfusion, usually due to antibodies in the recipient's blood reacting to donor leukocytes.

questions.text: A patient who receives recurrent transfusions for thalassemia develops fever and chills during this time. There is no evidence of hemolysis. Which of the following measures can decrease the rate of transfusion reactions?
questions.solution:
Correct option A: Leukoreduced RBCs:

  • The patient's presentation with fever and chills with no evidence of hemolysis is suggestive of a febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction.
  • Leukoreduced red blood cells (RBCs) refer to blood products that have undergone a process to remove or reduce the number of leukocytes.
  • White blood cells can trigger immune responses and cause transfusion reactions, including febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions.
  • Leukoreduced RBCs reduce the risk of febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions.

Incorrect options: Options B, C, and D do not reduce the risk of febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions.

questions.text: Which of the following is the major source of plasma Von Willebrand factor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Endothelial Cells:

  • Endothelial cells, which line the blood vessels, are the primary source of plasma von Willebrand factor.
  • These cells synthesize and release vWF into the bloodstream.
  • Von Willebrand factor produced by endothelial cells plays a crucial role in blood clotting and platelet adhesion to damaged blood vessel walls.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and C are incorrect.

questions.text: Acid mucin is stained by:
questions.solution:
Correct option B: Alcian blue:

  • Alcian blue staining is specifically used to detect and visualize acidic mucopolysaccharides, such as acid mucin.
  • It is often employed to identify mucin-producing cells, mucous glands, and mucin-rich connective tissues.
  • Alcian blue staining results in a blue or bluish-green color, indicating the presence of acid mucin.

Incorrect options:

Option A: PAS:

  • PAS staining is used to detect and highlight the presence of carbohydrates, including glycogen and mucopolysaccharides.
  • It is commonly used to stain structures such as basement membranes, glycogen granules, and fungal organisms.
  • PAS staining results in a pink-to-magenta coloration.

Option C: Masson trichrome:

  • Masson trichrome staining is a staining technique used to differentiate various tissue components.
  • It involves staining collagen fibers blue, cytoplasm and muscle fibers red, and nuclei dark red to black.
  • While Masson trichrome staining can help visualize connective tissues and collagen, it does not specifically target acid mucin.

Option D: Phosphotungstic acid haematoxylin (PTAH):

  • PTAH staining is commonly used to highlight muscle fibers and fibrin.
  • It is particularly useful in diagnosing muscle disorders and identifying abnormalities in muscle structure.

questions.text: What does the following image show?
questions.solution:
Correct option B: Emperipolesis:

  • Emperipolesisis a cellular process in which one cell is engulfed and contained within the cytoplasm of another cell without being degraded.
  • It is a non-destructive process, unlike phagocytosis or autophagy, where the engulfed material is typically broken down and degraded.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Autophagy:

  • Autophagy is a cellular process that involves the degradation and recycling of cellular components.
  • It is a mechanism by which cells remove damaged organelles, misfolded proteins, and other cytoplasmic constituents.
  • Autophagy plays a crucial role in maintaining cellular homeostasis and responding to various stress conditions.

Option C: Phagocytosis:

  • Phagocytosis is a process by which cells, such as macrophages and neutrophils, engulf and internalize solid particles, such as bacteria, cellular debris, or foreign substances.
  • The engulfed material is then enclosed within a membrane-bound vesicle called a phagosome, which fuses with lysosomes for degradation and destruction of the engulfed material.

Option D: Amoebic autophagy:

  • Amoebic autophagy refers to the autophagic process observed in amoebae, which are single-celled organisms.
  • It involves the engulfment and degradation of cellular components or particles by the amoebae to obtain nutrients or eliminate unwanted materials.

questions.text: A patient has been brought with severe bleeding to your ER. His blood group is unknown. Fresh frozen plasma from which of the following blood groups can be given?
questions.solution:
Correct option A: O:

  • Fresh frozen plasma from blood group O can be given to patients with an unknown blood group.
  • Blood group O individuals are considered universal plasma donors because their plasma lacks both A and B antigens on red blood cells, making it compatible with recipients of any ABO blood type without causing an ABO incompatibility reaction.

Incorrect options: Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: What is the color of the vacutainer that contains sodium fluoride?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Grey:

  • Sodium fluoride is used as an additive in vacutainers to prevent glycolysis in blood samples.
  • The vacutainer tube that contains sodium fluoride as an additive typically has a grey color.
  • The grey-top vacutainer is specifically designed for glucose and lactate determinations, as sodium fluoride acts as a glycolysis inhibitor.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Prolonged bleeding time is seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Von Willebrand Disease:

  • Prolonged bleeding time is seen in Von Willebrand disease.
  • Von Willebrand disease is a bleeding disorder caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of von Willebrand factor (VWF), a protein involved in platelet adhesion and blood clotting.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D: Prolonged bleeding time is not seen.

questions.text: What is the maximum duration for TRALI to occur after a blood transfusion?
questions.solution:
Correct option C: 6 hours:

  • Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) is a potentially severe complication that can occur after a blood transfusion.
  • It is characterized by the sudden onset of respiratory distress and non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema.
  • TRALI typically manifests within 6 hours after a blood transfusion.

Incorrect options: Options A, B, and D are incorrect.
